tweet: Glad to see the court side with students over the predatory student loan servicers that Betsy DeVos covers for. #DefendStudents https://twitter.com/rweingarten/status/1144401717951434752 …

We cannot continue on this course. We cannot unconditionally provide funding to this morally bankrupt administration and expect a different result. We have an obligation to insist on better. That is why I voted no.

I fear they will further exacerbate the humanitarian crisis rather than relieve it by treating immigrants as criminals, housing people in inhumane conditions that violate basic human rights, denying children and adults swift passage to relatives, and other punishing measures.
I had to vote no on the Senate bill because of my near certainty that the administration will misuse this money.
Unfortunately, the Senate has refused even to discuss the vital protections we included in the bill that already passed the House.
We hammered out strong protections for babies, children and families, and I felt privileged to work with such passionate and gifted colleagues to craft a bill that upheld our values.

We are caught up in an awful situation, with an amoral president and a spineless Republican Senate. House Democrats fought as best we could—item-by-item and line-by-line—to win real improvements for desperate and innocent people.
For the time being, we will have to count on citizen-led efforts like Proposal 2 to save us from decisions that erode fair democracy, like the one handed down today.
I’m proud that in 2018, we Michigan voters passed Proposal 2 to establish an independent citizens’ commission that will create fairer legislative maps starting in 2022.
The Supreme Court’s decision today further empowers politicians to misuse the redistricting process to rig elections by diminishing the voices of specific groups.
This is a sad day for democracy. Partisan gerrymandering is unjust regardless of the political party that employs it.

I will work to build a consensus in the House Democratic Caucus to begin this process, and I will reach across the aisle to engage Republican colleagues about the urgent need to protect our democracy.

I have concluded that the only way to get to the bottom of Mr. Trump’s activities and inform the public about what we learn is to centralize and expedite the process through one select committee with the focus, power and urgency that come with an impeachment inquiry.
After extensive discussion with colleagues on the committees of jurisdiction over various investigations...

I have concluded that, absent an impeachment inquiry, even if our appeals to the courts continue to succeed, they will follow a timeline far too slow to meet the needs of the American people for truth and justice.
However, I have watched the Trump administration’s stonewalling of our oversight activities with growing frustration.
Until today, I have maintained the position that we should neither rush to impeach President Trump nor take impeachment off the table.

His attitude towards foreign interference in our election process, the very heartbeat of our democracy, chills me to the bone, from his invitation to Vladimir Putin to meddle during 2016 to his comments this week about the 2020 election.

As the Mueller Report makes clear, on 10 or more occasions the President did obstruct justice or sought to obstruct justice, including by firing or attempting to fire people who were investigating him.
His refusal to share information about his taxes prevents the public from knowing the nature and extent of his conflicts of interest.

Mr. Trump has been violating the Emoluments Clause of the Constitution each and every day since he took office. His intertwining of his business dealings with governance and his profiting off his office are beyond improper.

When I became a member of the 116th Congress, I took an oath to protect and defend the Constitution of the United States. Today, I announce that I have concluded that the House has a duty to open an impeachment inquiry into the conduct of President Donald J. Trump.

The first job of a representative is listening to the people. I got really riled up today listening to the testimony of doctors, clinic directors,  parents and patients about our absurdly high prescription drug prices and barriers to care. We’ve GOT to fix this #ForThePeople.

This #PrideMonth we celebrate the love & community of LGBTQ people and the power they hold in living authentically. This month I recommit myself as a proud ally of the LGBTQ community, and to working to make Macomb & Oakland Counties accepting and inclusive communities for all.

The U.S. House of Representatives voted to pass the Equality Act with bipartisan support. I have offered my own bill, the Equal Dignity for Married Taxpayers Act, which would amend the tax code to remove gender-specific references in favor of language inclusive of LGBTQ couples.
Fortunately, our country is still making huge strides to protect the rights and dignity of LGBTQ people.

But we still have a long way to go. In many states, a person can still be fired for being gay. It is estimated that as many as 40 percent of homeless youth identify as LGBTQ, and laws that prevent LGBTQ couples from adopting children are advancing at a startling rate.

I am in awe by the progress our country has made in affirming the rights and dignity of LGBTQ people. It is because of the leadership and sacrifices of so many, especially transgender women of color and other intersectionally marginalized groups, that our country has progressed.
